learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
Jon Woolfrey
Faculty of Engineering &
Information Technology,
University of Technology Sydney

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Understand the central role of Continuous Improvement in Lean Production

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Define the principles of the Toyota Way

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Define the 14 principles proposed by Dr. Jeffrey Liker

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Lean is not:
     - A set of tools and techniques
     - A state
     - "most companies have focused too heavily on tools such as 5S and just-in-time without understanding lean as an entire system that must permeate an organization’s culture"
• Lean is:
     - A process
     - A guiding philosophy
• The Toyota Way is a set of guiding principles
• Lean forms an integral part of these principles

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• A set of management principles proposed by Toyota Motor Corporation
• Temporal & subject to change
• Reinforces the value of continuous improvement
• "the Toyota Way must evolve amid an everchanging business environment."
• 2 major components:
     - Continuous Improvement

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
Continuous Improvement
• Challenge
     - Create value
     - Spirit of challenge
     - Long-term perspective
     - Thorough decision-making
• Kaizen
     - Innovative thinking
     - Lean systems & structures
     - Organizational learning
• Genchi gembutsu
     - Go see the problem for yourself

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
Respect for People
• Respect
     - Respect for stakeholders
     - Mutual trust and responsibility
     - Sincere communication
• Teamwork
     - Education & development
     - Respect for the individual

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Proposed by Dr. Jeffrey Liker in 2004
• Provides an alternate perspective on the Toyota Way
• 4P’s:
     1. Long-term Philosophy
     2. The right Process will produce the right results
     3. Add value to the organization by developing People
     4. Continuously solving root Problems drives organizational learning
         i.e. continuous improvement

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
1. Long-term Philosophy
     1. Base management decisions on a long-term philosophy, even at the expense of short-term goals
2. The right process will produce the right results
     2. Create continuous flow to expose problems
     3. Use “pull” systems to avoid overproduction
     4. Level out the workload (mura, muri, heijunka)
     5. Build a culture of stop-and-fix (jidoka)
     6. Standardize tasks and processes (mura)
     7. Use visual controls so no problems are hidden
     8. Use only reliable, thoroughly-tested technology
3. Add value by developing people
     9. Grow leaders who understand the work and live the philosophy
     10. Develop exceptional people
     11. Respect your extended network of partners and suppliers

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
Professor Holly Ott
Production and Supply Chain Management
Chair: Prof. Martin Grunow
TUM School of Management

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Outline the history of the Toyota Motor Corporation from the Toyota Automatic Loom Works.

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • Describe the historical drivers for the development of the Toyota Production System at Toyota and identify the important contributors to TPS.

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • List the core elements of the Toyota Production System.

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • 1926 Sakichi Toyoda: Toyoda Automatic Loom Works

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • 1933 Kiichiro Toyoda: automotive division. Produced military trucks during WWII

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • 1926 Sakichi Toyoda: Toyoda Automatic Loom Works

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • 1933 Kiichiro Toyoda: automotive division. Produced military trucks during WWII

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • After war, shortages, little cash... Ford Motor Co. at the Rouge plant near Detroit producing 7,000 cars/day. Toyota producing 200 per year

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content: • 1940s Eiji Toyoda ... needed to do things differently!

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Toyota Production System - Lean Manufacturing
• Taiichi Ohno is credited for creating the system
• Dr. Shigeo Shingo, author Single Minute Exchange of Die procedure.
• Quantity Control (Just In Time)
• Quality Control & Improvement
• Waste and Cost Control
• The term "Lean" is from John Krafcik's 1988 article "Triumph of Lean Production Systems."

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Maximize share of value-adding activities
     - Elimination of "waste" (muda)
     - Strive to minimize batch sizes (ideally single piece flow)
     - Build processes based on true customer requirements
• Implement stable, standardized processes
     - Workplace organization
     - Standard Operating Procedures
     - Fail-safe processes (Jidoka)

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
• Create a self-learning, continuously improving organization
  - Create transparency on problems/facilitate immediate identification
  - Conduct rigorous root-cause problem solving
  - Make continuous improvement part of the daily work
• Take a holistic Supply Chain perspective
  - Customer requirements-driven perspective
  - Backwards integration to include suppliers
• People development is the key success factor
  - Employee skill building is an important part of the TPS

learning_material.label: text_box
learning_material.text_content:
Professor Holly Ott
Production and Supply Chain Management
Chair: Prof. Martin Grunow
TUM School of Management
